facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 551 to 560 of 1961 are appeals from the judgment and order dated December 9, 1955 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 323, 324, 351 to 357 and 359 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 551 to 560 of 1961. Appeals from the judgment and order dated December 9, 1955 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 323, 324, 351 to 357 and 359 of 1955.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on November 20, 1962 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 20. The judgment of the Court was delivered by. SHAH., J.-

facts.text: There are eight Maths at Udipi in the South Kanara District reputed to be founded by Shree Madhvacharya.

anchor.surface_text: At Udipi in the South Kanara District there are eight Maths which are reputed to be founded by Shree Madhvacharya, an exponent of the dualistic philosophy.

facts.text: Each of the eight Maths is presided over by a Mathadhipati or Swami who is invariably a Brahmin Sanyasin.

anchor.surface_text: Each of these Maths is presided over by a Mathadhipati or Swami who is invariably a Brahmin Sanyasin.

facts.text: Shri Krishna Devaru Math is administered according to long-standing usage by the Swamis of the eight Maths in turn, each for two years.

anchor.surface_text: There exists another Math known as Shri Krishna Devaru Math of which the administration is carried on according to long-standing usage by the Swamis of the eight Maths in turn, each Swami administering for two years.

facts.text: Sri Kanchi Kamakoti Peetam Math is presided over by Shree Sankaracharya Swamigal.

anchor.surface_text: There is also the Sri Kanchi Kamakoti Peetam Math of which Shree Sank- aracharya Swamigal is the presiding head.

facts.text: Ten appeals are directed against orders passed by the Madras High Court refusing to declare provisions of the Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: These ten appeals are directed against orders passed by the High Court of Madras refusing to declare the provisions aforesaid ultra vires the State Legislature.

facts.text: Provincial Legislature of Madras enacted Hindu Religious Endowments Act II of 1927 for proper management of Hindu religious endowments.

anchor.surface_text: In order to ensure proper management of Hindu religious endowments, the Provincial Legislature of Madras enacted the Hindu Religious Endowments Act. II of 1927.

facts.text: An enquiry was commenced before the Hindu Religious Endowments Board for Shirur Math to frame a scheme due to alleged mismanagement by the Swami.

anchor.surface_text: An enquiry was companymenced before the Hindu Religious Endowments Board for ascertaining whether in the interests of the Shirur Math  one of the eight maths at Udipi  a scheme for the administration of the Math be framed, it being alleged that the affairs of the Math were mismanaged by the Swami.

facts.text: Swami of Shirur Math filed petition in Madras High Court challenging vires of Act II of 1927.

anchor.surface_text: The Swami filed a petition in the High Court of Madras challenging the vires of Act II of 1927, and especially the provisions under which the scheme was sought to be framed.

facts.text: Act II of 1927 was repealed and substituted by Madras Act XIX of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of that petition, Act 11 of 1927 was repealed by the Madras Legialature and was substituted by Act XIX of 1951, enacting diverse provisions relating to the governance, management and administration of Hindu Religious Endowments.

facts.text: Madras High Court declared several provisions of Act XIX of 1951 ultra vires infringing Arts. 19(1)(f), 25, 26, 27 and s.76(1) incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madras declared several provisions of the Act ultra vires, as infringing Arts. 19  1   f , 25, 26 and 27 of the Constitution. The Court also declared s. 76  1  ultra vires because the State Legislature had thereby assumed powers to legislate for levy of a tax on the income of religious endowments which the State Legislature was incompetent to exercise.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Commissioner HRE Madras v Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt declared invalid ss.21,30(2),31,55,63-69,76(1).

anchor.surface_text: This Court declared invalid s. 21  provision authorising the Commissioner and his subordinates to enter premises of religious endowments or places of worship in the exercise of powers companyferred or duties imposed by or under the Act , s. 30  2   requiring the swamis to be guided by the instructions of the Commissioner or the Area Committee in the matter of incurring expenditure , s. 31  relating to expenditure of surplus income with the sanction of the Commissioner , s. 55  dealing with Mahants powers over pathakanikas personal gifts , S. 55  dealing with Commissioners authority to require the trustees of the Endowments to appoint a Manager  and ss. 63 to 69  relating to numberification of religious institutions and invoking thereby certain penal companysequences.  This Court also held that s. 76  1  whichauthorised levy of companytributions at the rate number exceeding five per cent of the income of the endowments was beyond the power of the State Legislature to enact.

facts.text: Madras Legislature amended Act XIX of 1951 by Act XXVII of 1954 which received President's sanction on September 22, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras Legislature amended Act XXVII of 1954 which received the Presidents sanction on  1  1954 S. C. R. 1005. September 22, 1954, and thereby provisions which were declared by this Court ultra vires, were altered or omitted and some new provisions were enacted with a view to make the enactment companysistent with the law declared by this Court.

facts.text: Appellants, heads of ten maths, filed petitions challenging validity of diverse provisions of the amended Act.

anchor.surface_text: Petitions were then filed by the appellants-heads of ten maths--challenging the validity of diverse provisions of the amended Act.

facts.text: Madras High Court by order dated April 25, 1955 declared ss.21,30(2),31,76(5) and Rule 10 invalid but upheld ss.52(1)(f),55,76(1)(2),80,81,82.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its order dated April 25, 1955 declared ss. 21, 30  2 , 31 and 76  5 , and Rule 10 framed under s. 100 2  invalid. The High Court, however, upheld the validity of ss. 52  1   f , 55, 76  1   2 , 80, 81 and 82.

facts.text: Territory where maths are situated integrated with State of Mysore as from November 1, 1956 by States Reorganisation Act, 1956; governed by Act XIX of 1951 per s.119.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be observed that Act XIX of 1951 has been repealed by the Madras State Legislature and has been substituted by Act XXII of 1959, but we are number called upon to adjudicate upon the validity of the provisions of the new Act because the territory in which these maths are situated has, by the provisions of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 been integrated with the State of Mysore as from November 1, 1956 and by virtue of s. 119 of the States Reorganisation Act these maths companytinue to be governed by Act XIX of 1951 till that Act is modified or repealed by the Mysore State Legisture.

facts.text: During September 30, 1951 to June 30, 1952, total receipts under relevant heads were Rs. 3,16,013 and Rs. 2,27,531; total expenditure Rs. 6,93,539.

anchor.surface_text: During the period from 30th September 1951 to 30th June 1952 the total receipts under the head XXXVI Miscellaneous- c.  Miscellaneous Administration of Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 amounts to Rs. 3,16,013-1-3 and the total receipts under XLVI-Miscellaneous  d  fees for Government Audit by way of companytribution recovered from the religious institutions amounted to Rs. 2,27,531-4-10. The total expenditure during the said period towards salary and allowances of the officers and staff companytingencies and fees paid to private auditors for auditing the accounts of religious institutions amounted to Rs. 6,93,539-10-3.

facts.text: By end of fasli year 1364, arrears in collection of contributions exceeded 15.50 lakhs; total collections Rs. 19.74 lakhs, balance Rs. 15.75 lakhs, expenditure Rs. 26.4 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: J appears from the Chart that there were large arrears in the companylection of companytributions and by the end of the fasli year 1364 the arrears exceeded 15.50 lakhs. An abstract at the foot of the chart shows that the total actual companylections amounted to Rs. 19.74 lakhs and the balance recoverable for the four fasli years was Rs. 15.75 lakhs. The total expenditure for 31 out of the four years was Rs. 26.4 lakhs.

facts.text: Commissioner received investments exceeding Rs. 18 lakhs accumulated over nearly 25 years under Act of 1927.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was also invited to a statement of account showing that the Commissioner received when the Act of 1951 was brought into force a total investment in fixed deposits, Government stock certificates, debentures of companyorative land mortgage bank, national savings certificates and in banks a total account exceeding Rs. 18 lakhs.

facts.text: Supreme Court held ss.52(1)(f),55,76(1)(2),80,81,82 intra vires; appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court was right in declaring ss. 52 1  f , 55, 76 1   2 , 80, 81.,and 82 intra vires. The appeals therefore, fail and are dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: the validity of ss.52(1)(f), 55, 76(1)(2), 80, 81 and 82 of the Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act XIX of 1951 as amended by Act XXVII of 1954

At Udipi in the South Kanara District there are eight Maths

issues.text: whether s.52(1)(f) which enables a suit to be filed on the score of waste of funds or properties of the institution or application of such funds or properties for purposes unconnected with the institution, infringes the fundamental right of the Mathadhipati under Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by counsel for the appellants that s. 52 1 f which enables a suit to be filed on the score of waste of funds or properties of the institution or application of such funds or properties for purposes unconnected with the institution, infringes the fundamental right of the Mathadhipati under Art. 19 1 f of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether Section 55 as amended imposes an unreasonable restriction upon the fundamental right of the Mahant over pathakanikas

anchor.surface_text: Section 55, before it was amended, was challenged in the earlier proceeding as being invalid on the ground that it sought to place an unreasonable restriction upon the powers of the Mahant over gifts personal to him.

issues.text: whether the levy of contribution under ss.76(1) and (2) as amended constitutes a valid fee with quid pro quo or an invalid tax

anchor.surface_text: The next section challenged is s. 76 1 . The section, as it originally stood before it was amended, provided 76 1 In respect of the services rendered by the Government and their officers, every religious institution shall, from the income derived by it, pay to the Government annually such contribution

whether s.82 validating prior contributions retrospectively under ss.76(1) and (2) is within legislative competence

anchor.surface_text: But counsel for the appellants says that over the income, the Mahant has absolute powers of disposal, and s. 52 1 f which authories his removal on the ground that he has applied the funds or properties of the institution for purposes unconnected with the institution places an unreasonable restriction upon the right of property vested in the Mahant.

arguments.claim: Position of Mahant blends office and property rights protected under Art.19(1)(f); unreasonable restrictions void

anchor.surface_text: In the Commissioner, Hindu Endownents, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt Mukherjea, J., observed at p. 1019 There is no reason why the word property as used in article 19 1 f of the constitution, should not be given a liberal and wide connotation and should not be extended to those welt recognized types of interest which have the insignia or characteristics of proprietary right.

arguments.claim: s.52(1)(f) does not impose unreasonable restriction as it aligns with trustee duties and math customs

anchor.surface_text: By s. 52 1 f application of funds or properties for purposes unconnected with the institution, i. e. purposes for which the custom of the institution does not warrant application, is a ground for removal. It cannot be said that by enacting a provision which enables a Court, in an appropriate case, to remove a Mahant if it be found that he has applied the funds or the properties of the institution for purposes unconnected with the institution, any unreasonable restriction is sought to be placed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Amended s.55 defines pathakanikas as gifts to head of math (in trust); requires accounts and spending per customs, consistent with trustee role

arguments.claim: Pathakanikas in s.55 are gifts to math in trust, not personal; obligation to spend per custom reasonable

anchor.surface_text: By express enactment the expression pathakanikas for the purpose of s. 55 as amended, means gifts of property made to a Mahant as the head of the Math. By that section, the Mahant is required to keep regular accounts of receipts of such gifts and is entitled to spend the same in accordance with the customs and usages of the institution, for such pathakanikas received by the Mahant are gifts to the Mahant as the head of the math and therefore in trust gifts to the Math.

holdings.text: ss.52(1)(f), 55, 76(1)(2), 80, 81 and 82 of the Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act XIX of 1951 as amended by Act XXVII of 1954 are intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court was right in declaring ss. 52 1 f , 55, 76 1   2 , 80, 81.,and 82 intra vires. The appeals therefore, fail and are dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly upheld validity; provisions do not infringe fundamental rights or exceed legislative competence; amendments remedy prior defects identified in Shirur Mutt case.

holdings.text: s.52(1)(f) does not amount to an unreasonable restriction upon the fundamental right of the Mahant in the property under his management.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the provision which authorises the institution of a suit for removal of a Mahant where he is found to have wasted the funds or properties of the institution or has applied such funds or properties for purposes wholly unconnected with the institution does number amount to an unreason. able restriction upon the fundamental right of the Mahant in the property under his management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mahant holds blended office and property right subject to trustee duties; provision enforces custom and usage, aligns with precedents like Shirur Mutt and Privy Council cases; reasonable under Art.19(5) in public interest.

holdings.text: Obligations imposed by s.55 as amended upon the Mahant to maintain accounts of pathakanikas and spend in accordance with customs cannot be regarded as an unreasonable restriction upon his fundamental right.

anchor.surface_text: Obligations imposed upon the Mahant to maintain regular accounts of the receipts of pethakanikas of the character defined in s. 55 and to utilise the same in Accordance with the customs and usages of the institution cannot be regarded as an unreasonable restriction upon the fundamental right of the Mahant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amended definition treats pathakanikas as trust gifts to math head; consistent with trustee obligations; distinguishes from personal gifts; remedies prior invalidity.

holdings.text: Levy under ss.76(1) and (2) as amended is a valid fee, not a tax, due to earmarking in separate fund with reasonable relation to services.

anchor.surface_text: The Court in the earlier case pointed out that the levy of an annual contribution permitted by s. 76(1) ... A levy in the nature of a fee does number cease to be of that character merely because there is an element of companypulsion or companyrciveness present in it, number is it a postulate of a fee that it must have direct relation to the actual services rendered by the authority to individual who btains the benefit of the service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendments remedy defects: contributions to Commissioner, not Government; separate fund under s.81; for specific services; no reliable evidence of disproportion post-amendment.

holdings.text: Sections 80 and 81 are intra vires as they establish distinct fund unrelated to general revenues.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Integral to fee mechanism; supports quid pro quo by segregating funds for administration expenses.

holdings.text: s.82 validating prior contributions retrospectively is intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: challenge to the vires of s. 82  2  must fail. In our view the High Court was right in declaring ss. 52 1  f , 55, 76 1   2 , 80, 81.,and 82 intra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrospective legislation competent; denudes tax character, converts to fees; supported by precedents like J.K. Jute Mills; within List III powers.

holdings.text: State Legislature competent to levy fee under Seventh Schedule List III Item 28 r/w Item 47 for services to religious endowments, prospectively or retrospectively.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent legislative power for fees on services rendered; no constitutional limitation on retrospectivity.

holdings.text: s.55 as amended does not apply to pathakanikas proved to be personal gifts to the Mahant.

anchor.surface_text: Section 55 as amended will number apply to pathakanikas which are proved to be gifts personal to the Mahant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express definition limited to gifts as head of math; distinguishes broader traditional meaning in s.52(1)(g).

holdings.text: High Court's observation that Mahant limited to not spending for wicked/immoral purposes not warranted by Shirur Mutt judgment.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, say that the observations made by the learned judges of the High Court that it was decided by this Court in the Commissioner, Hindu Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt that the real limitations on the Mathadhipathi are that he should number spend any of the monies of the Math for wicked or immoral purposes does number seem to be war-ranted by anything contained in the judgment of this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarification of prior precedent; dictum not approved.

precedents.cited_holding: s.76(1) authorised levy of contributions beyond power of State Legislature as it was a tax

anchor.surface_text: Arunachallam Chetty v. Venkatachalapathi Guruswamigal 1 dealing with the title which a Mahant of a math has in the property of the math, the judicial Committee of the Privy Council observed two propositions may be cited as number express- ing the general state of the law.

precedents.cited_proposition: Nature of ownership of Mahant is ownership in trust for the institution; surplus income to be added to capital not for personal enjoyment
precedents.cited_holding: Mahant bound to add surplus to capital of estate; personal use apart from dignity subverts usage

anchor.surface_text: Ram Parkaah Das v. Anand Das there are varieties of circumstances and tenure, and in respect to these the usage and custom of the math fall to be determined.

precedents.cited_proposition: Varieties of circumstances and tenure; usage and custom form the law of the math

precedents.citation: Vidya Varuthi Thirtha v. Balusami Ayyangar 1

anchor.surface_text: Vidya Varuthi Thirtha v. Balusami Ayyangar 1 the judicial Committee dealing with the application of Arts. 134 and 144 to suits for recovery of property alienated by a former Mathadhipati observed It is also to be remembered that a trust in the sense in which the expression is used in English law, is unknown in the Hindu System, pure and simple.

precedents.case_name: Vidya Varuthi Thirtha v Balusami Ayyangar
precedents.cited_proposition: Trust unknown in Hindu law; gifts to holy persons carry obligations by usage; maths have discretion subject to custom

precedents.citation: The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1   to which we have already referred in setting out the history of this case  Mukherjea, J., speaking for the Court, observed He is certainly number a trusteee in the strict sense.
